# Sagging (fashion)

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Sagger_in_NYC.jpg/220px-
Sagger_in_NYC.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sagger_in_NYC.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Sagger_in_NYC.jpg "Enlarge")

A sagger in New York City.

**Sagging** is a manner of wearing [trousers](/wiki/Trousers "Trousers") or
[jeans](/wiki/Jeans "Jeans") which
[sag](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/sag#Verb "wikt:sag") so that the top of
the trousers or jeans are significantly below the waist, sometimes revealing
much of the underwear.

Sagging is predominantly a male fashion. Women's wearing of [low-rise
jeans](/wiki/Low-rise_jeans "Low-rise jeans") to reveal their
[G-string](/wiki/G-string "G-string") underwear (the "[whale
tail](/wiki/Whale_tail "Whale tail")") is not generally described as
sagging.[1] A person wearing sagging trousers is sometimes called a
"sagger",[2] and in some countries this practice is known as "low-
riding".[3][4] It has become popular since the popularity of wearing brightly
colored and patterned "[boxer shorts](/wiki/Boxer_shorts "Boxer
shorts")".[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Sagging first peaked in popularity during the 1990s and remained popular into
the mid 2000s, but it has recently made a comeback in the 2010s, with
celebrities like [Justin Bieber](/wiki/Justin_Bieber "Justin Bieber"), [Liam
Payne](/wiki/Liam_Payne "Liam Payne"), [Ross Lynch](/wiki/Ross_Lynch "Ross
Lynch") and more bringing back the fashion trend. Sagging in the 1990s usually
focused on baggy trousers with plaid boxers, but in the 2010s sagging has
become popular with skinny jeans and branded boxer-briefs.

## Origin[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sagging_\(fashion\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Origin")]

The style was popularized by skaters and [hip-hop](/wiki/Hip-hop "Hip-hop")
artists in the 1990s.[5][6] It later became a symbol of freedom and cultural
awareness among some youths[7] or a symbol of their rejection of the values of
mainstream society.[8]

It is often claimed the style originated from the United States prison system
where [belts](/wiki/Belt_\(clothing\) "Belt \(clothing\)") are sometimes
prohibited[9] and there can be a lack of appropriately sized clothing.[5][10]

##
Reaction[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sagging_\(fashion\)&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Reaction")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Sagging_crop.jpg/220px-
Sagging_crop.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sagging_crop.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Sagging_crop.jpg "Enlarge")

Two male Detroiters sagging their pants in 2007

During the first decade of the 21st century, many North American local
governments, school systems, transit agencies, and even airlines passed laws
and regulations against the practice of wearing sagging pants, although no
state or federal laws have been enacted banning the practice.[11] US
presidential candidate [Barack Obama](/wiki/Barack_Obama "Barack Obama"),
speaking just before the [2008 US Presidential
Election](/wiki/United_States_Presidential_Election,_2008 "United States
Presidential Election, 2008"), appeared on [MTV](/wiki/MTV "MTV") and said
that laws banning the practice of wearing low-slung pants that expose one's
underwear were "a waste of time ... Having said that, brothers should pull up
their pants. You are walking by your mother, your grandmother, your underwear
is showing. What's wrong with that? Come on. Some people might not want to see
your underwear. I'm one of them."[12]

In June 2007 the Town Council of [Delcambre,
Louisiana](/wiki/Delcambre,_Louisiana "Delcambre, Louisiana"), passed an
[indecent exposure](/wiki/Indecent_exposure "Indecent exposure") ordinance,
which prohibited intentionally wearing trousers in such a way as to show
underwear.[13] In March 2008 the [Hahira, Georgia](/wiki/Hahira,_Georgia
"Hahira, Georgia") City Council passed a controversial clothing ordinance, in
the name of public safety, that bans citizens from wearing pants with top
below the waist that reveal skin or undergarments. The council was split 2–2,
but the tie was broken by the mayor.[14]

Benetta Standly, statewide organizer for the [American Civil Liberties
Union](/wiki/American_Civil_Liberties_Union "American Civil Liberties Union")
of Georgia stated, "In Atlanta, we see this as [racial
profiling](/wiki/Racial_profiling "Racial profiling") ... It's going to target
African-American male youths. There's a fear with people associating the way
you dress with crimes being committed."[15] The interim police chief of
[Flint, Michigan](/wiki/Flint,_Michigan "Flint, Michigan") ordered the arrest
of saggers for disorderly conduct; however, as of August
2008[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Sagging_\(fashion\)&action=edit),
only warnings had been issued. The local chapter of the ACLU threatened legal
action in response, saying that sagging did not violate the Flint disorderly
conduct ordinance[16] and a Florida judge threw out a case brought under a
similar rule, as being unconstitutional.[17]

Sagging clothing is a violation of some school dress codes,[3][18][19][20] and
the prohibition has been supported in the court system.[21]

Two weeks after the "[Pants on the Ground](/wiki/Pants_on_the_Ground "Pants on
the Ground")" video became popular thanks to _[American
Idol](/wiki/American_Idol "American Idol")_ (_see below_), a
[billboard](/wiki/Billboard "Billboard") campaign against the style of sagging
pants was launched in the [Dallas, Texas](/wiki/Dallas,_Texas "Dallas,
Texas"), area. The billboards feature [Big Mama
Joseph](/wiki/Josephine_Joseph_\(Soul_Food\) "Josephine Joseph \(Soul Food\)")
from the 1997 film _[Soul Food](/wiki/Soul_Food_\(film\) "Soul Food
\(film\)")_ saying, "Pull 'Em Up!" and asks youngsters to "Keep it a secret!"
The campaign is the brainchild of Dallas Mayor Pro Tem Dwaine R. Caraway, and
uses advertising space donated by [Clear Channel Outdoor](/wiki/Clear_Channel
"Clear Channel").[22] Another billboard campaign against sagging pants was
launched in [Brooklyn](/wiki/Brooklyn "Brooklyn"), [New
York](/wiki/New_York_\(state\) "New York \(state\)") by New York [State
Senator](/wiki/State_Senator "State Senator") [Eric
Adams](/wiki/Eric_Adams_\(politician\) "Eric Adams \(politician\)") on March
28, 2010.[23] In May 2010 New York State Senate President [Malcolm
Smith](/wiki/Malcolm_Smith_\(U.S._politician\) "Malcolm Smith \(U.S.
politician\)") used [US$](/wiki/US$ "US$")2,200 from his campaign fund to
launch a similar campaign in [Queens](/wiki/Queens "Queens").[24]

At the [2010 Winter Olympics](/wiki/2010_Winter_Olympics "2010 Winter
Olympics") in [Vancouver](/wiki/Vancouver "Vancouver"), Japanese
[snowboarder](/wiki/Snowboarding "Snowboarding") [Kazuhiro
Kokubo](/wiki/Kazuhiro_Kokubo "Kazuhiro Kokubo") was barred from participating
in the opening ceremonies due to dressing sloppily, including a loosened tie,
shirt hanging out, and sagging pants.[25]

In the fall of 2010 at Westside Middle School in [Memphis,
Tennessee](/wiki/Memphis,_Tennessee "Memphis, Tennessee"), the policy on
handling sagging pants is for students to pull them up or get "Urkeled", a
reference to the character [Steve Urkel](/wiki/Steve_Urkel "Steve Urkel") of
the 1990s television show _[Family Matters](/wiki/Family_Matters "Family
Matters")_. In this practice, teachers would pull their pants up and attach
them there using [zip ties](/wiki/Zip_tie "Zip tie"). Students would also have
their photo taken and posted on a board in the hallway, for all of their
classmates to see. In an interview with [WMC-TV](/wiki/WMC-TV "WMC-TV"),
Principal Bobby White stated that the general idea is to fight [pop
culture](/wiki/Popular_culture "Popular culture") with pop culture.[26] One
teacher at the school claimed to have "Urkeled" up to 80 students per week,
although after five weeks students got the message, and the number dropped to
18.[27]

On November 23, 2010, [Albany, Georgia](/wiki/Albany,_Georgia "Albany,
Georgia") passed a city ordinance that banned the wearing of pants or skirts
with top more than three inches below the top of the hips, and imposed a fine
of $25 for the first offense, increasing to up to $250 for subsequent
offenses. By September 2011, City Attorney Nathan Davis reported that 187
citations had been issued and fines of $3,916 collected.[28]

On December 8, 2010, the city of [Opa-locka, Florida](/wiki/Opa-locka,_Florida
"Opa-locka, Florida") voted unanimously on a $250 fine or 10 hours of
community service for individuals who did not pull their pants up.[29]

In [Fort Worth, Texas](/wiki/Fort_Worth,_Texas "Fort Worth, Texas"), the local
transportation authority implemented a policy in June 2011 that prohibited any
passenger from boarding a bus while wearing sagging pants that exposes their
underwear or buttocks. Signs were posted on buses saying, "Pull 'em up or find
another ride", and one City Council member was looking for funds for a
billboard campaign. The communications manager for the Fort Worth
Transportation Authority said that on the first day the policy was enforced,
50 people were removed from buses for wearing improper pants. Some complained
about the policy, but the overall response was positive.[7]

A state law went into effect in [Florida](/wiki/Florida "Florida") for the
2011–2012 school year banning the practice of sagging while at school. Pupils
found in violation receive a verbal warning for the first offense, followed by
parental notification by the principal for the second offense, which will
require the parent to bring a change of clothing to school. Students would
then face [in-school suspension](/wiki/Suspension_\(punishment\) "Suspension
\(punishment\)") for subsequent violations.[30]

[University of New Mexico](/wiki/University_of_New_Mexico "University of New
Mexico") football player Deshon Marman was removed from a [U.S.
Airways](/wiki/U.S._Airways "U.S. Airways") flight bound for [Albuquerque, New
Mexico](/wiki/Albuquerque,_New_Mexico "Albuquerque, New Mexico") for wearing
sagging pants.[31] A few months later [Green Day](/wiki/Green_Day "Green Day")
singer [Billie Joe Armstrong](/wiki/Billie_Joe_Armstrong "Billie Joe
Armstrong") was removed from a [Southwest Airlines](/wiki/Southwest_Airlines
"Southwest Airlines") flight from [Oakland](/wiki/Oakland,_California
"Oakland, California") to [Burbank, California](/wiki/Burbank,_California
"Burbank, California") for the same reason.[31]

In April 2012 Alabama County Circuit Judge John Bush sentenced 20-year-old
LaMarcus Ramsey to three days in jail for appearing in court with sagging blue
jeans that exposed his underwear, telling him, "You are in [contempt of
court](/wiki/Contempt_of_court "Contempt of court") because you showed your
butt in court."[32]

On June 12, 2013, the Town Council of [Wildwood, New
Jersey](/wiki/Wildwood,_New_Jersey "Wildwood, New Jersey"), located on the
[Jersey Shore](/wiki/Jersey_Shore "Jersey Shore"), voted unanimously to ban
sagging pants from the town's boardwalk.[33]

In [Ocala, FL](/wiki/Ocala,_FL "Ocala, FL"), a law was passed against sagging
jeans, violators face a $500 fine or up to six months in jail. Something
similar was done in Wildwood, NJ.[34]

On July 5, 2016 an ordinance was passed in Timmonsville, SC that punishes
sagging pants. If the law is violated, offenders could face up to a $600
fine.[35]

## Music
videos[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sagging_\(fashion\)&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Music videos")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Travis_Scott_sagging.jpg/220px-
Travis_Scott_sagging.jpg)](/wiki/File:Travis_Scott_sagging.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Travis_Scott_sagging.jpg "Enlarge")

American rapper [Travis Scott](/wiki/Travis_Scott_\(musician\) "Travis Scott
\(musician\)") sagging his pants while performing in 2015.

Sagging has been ridiculed in [music videos](/wiki/Music_video "Music video"),
first, in the 1996 song "Back Pockets on the Floor" performed by The Green
Brothers of [Highland Park, Michigan](/wiki/Highland_Park,_Michigan "Highland
Park, Michigan").[36] Another song in 2007 by Dewayne Brown of [Dallas,
Texas](/wiki/Dallas,_Texas "Dallas, Texas") entitled "Pull Your Pants Up" has
a similar message.[37] On January 13, 2010, ["General" Larry
Platt](/wiki/Larry_Platt "Larry Platt") performed "[Pants on the
Ground](/wiki/Pants_on_the_Ground "Pants on the Ground")" during auditions for
the ninth season of _[American Idol](/wiki/American_Idol_\(season_9\)
"American Idol \(season 9\)")_ in [Atlanta, Georgia](/wiki/Atlanta,_Georgia
"Atlanta, Georgia").[38] In 2012 a 9-year-old rapper named Amor "Lilman"
Arteaga wrote a song titled "Pull Ya Pants Up," and made a music video with an
appearance by Brooklyn president [Marty Markowitz](/wiki/Marty_Markowitz
"Marty Markowitz").[39]
